sen.j: 杉玉（すぎたま）とは、スギの葉（穂先）を集めてボール状にした造形物。
sen.e: Sugitama is a craft made from collection of fir leaves (tip) and shaped into a ball.

sen.j: 酒林（さかばやし）とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is also called as Sakabayashi (sake forest).

sen.j: 日本酒の造り酒屋などの軒先に緑の杉玉を吊すことで、新酒が出来たことを知らせる役割を果たす。
sen.e: It functions as a notice that new sake is made by hanging down green sugitama from the edge of a roof of sake (Japanese rice wine) brewery building.
It functions as a notice that new sake is finished when a green sugitama is hung from the eaves of a sake brewery.

sen.j: 「日本酒上槽を始めました」という意味である。
sen.e: It means 'we've started to joso (extraction to separate sake from sake lees by applying pressure) of Japanese sake (Japanese rice wine).'
It means 'we've started to press the sake.'

sen.j: 吊るされたばかりの杉玉はまだ蒼々としているが、やがて枯れて茶色がかってくる。
sen.e: The sugitama that is newly hung is still looking fresh green but eventually withers into brown.
The sugitama that is newly hung is fresh and green, but eventually withers to brown.

sen.j: この色の変化がまた人々に、新酒の日本酒熟成の具合を物語る。
sen.e: This change of color tells people the ripening of the newly made Japanese sake.

sen.j: 今日では、酒屋の看板のように受け取られがちであるが、元々は酒の神様に感謝を捧げるものであったとされる。
sen.e: It is interpreted as the sign of the liquor shop nowadays, but originally for the offerings of the god of sake.
It is interpreted as the sign of the liquor shop nowadays, but originally was an offering for the god of sake.

sen.j: 起源は、酒神大神神社の三輪山のスギにあやかったという。
sen.e: This originated from the fir growing on Mount Miwa of the Shushin Oomiwa Shrine (Great God of Sake Shrine).

sen.j: 俗に一休の作とされるうた「極楽は何処の里と思ひしに杉葉立てたる又六が門」は、杉玉をうたったものである。
sen.e: The poem supposedly made by Ikkyu stated, 'Paradise is not far but within one's heart and can be discovered while drinking sake,' and sang of sugitama.

sen.e: There is a theory that fir leaves are hung since these leaves prevent the sake from decaying.
